channel.title: My FileDownloader

item.title: My FileDownloader
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

It might be better to recreate a new buffer for every so many bytes. I say this because the file could be 300 megs; who wants to load 300 megs into a byte[]? So, like my downloader does, keep creating an array of an initial buffer size, and keep doing that until you’ve written it all.

Read full topic

Just wondering why require a http download? FTP is faster.

You really dont have to worry about enforcing the type of connection, catch the MalformedURLException and print a error or whatever you want and exit.

item.title: My FileDownloader
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

Let’s play “Spot the difference.”

[code].method public void a()
.limit stack 2
.limit locals 4
ldc “Herro der”
astore_1
ldc “Lel”
astore_2
new java.lang.StringBuilder
dup
invokespecial void java.lang.StringBuilder.()
aload_1
invokevirtual java.lang.StringBuilder java.lang.StringBuilder.append(java.lang.String)
aload_2
invokevirtual java.lang.StringBuilder java.lang.StringBuilder.append(java.lang.String)
invokevirtual java.lang.String java.lang.StringBuilder.toString()
astore_3
return
.end method

.method public void x()
.limit stack 2
.limit locals 4
ldc “Herro der”
astore_1
ldc “Lel”
astore_2
new java.lang.StringBuilder
dup
invokespecial void java.lang.StringBuilder.()
aload_1
invokevirtual java.lang.StringBuilder java.lang.StringBuilder.append(java.lang.String)
aload_2
invokevirtual java.lang.StringBuilder java.lang.StringBuilder.append(java.lang.String)
invokevirtual java.lang.String java.lang.StringBuilder.toString()
astore_3
return
.end method
[/code]

[code] public void a() {
String a = “Herro der”;
String b = “Lel”;
String c = a + b;
}

public void x() {
	String a = "Herro der";
	String b = "Lel";
	String c = new StringBuilder().append(a).append(b).toString();
}[/code]

Meh. Someone probably already pointed this out, but I wanted to post CFParsed code to annoy everyone (Since we all know no one likes it)

Read full topic

item.title: My FileDownloader
item.dc:creator: @RLN RLN
item.description:
@RLN wrote:

[quote=“ownagesbot, post:15, topic:64966”][quote author=Javacisnotrecognized link=topic=94284.msg980280#msg980280 date=1173240492]

yes it does look good
but you shouldn’t put the “new StringBuilder().append” in it, it looks worse

That’s what the compiler puts in if you use + on strings. And it looks nice, other than that there is no need to put in the constructor what you could have stuffed into main…
[/quote]
Actually it isn’t… StringBuilder is never a string until .toString() is called. Therefore friend, .append doesn’t do the same as + on a string. Although it gives similar results. Anyway more to the point.[/quote]That didn’t make sense, because it has nothing to do with what lawl said. lawl said that for all concatenation with variables, javac uses stringbuilder.append, and he is right. (Unless the strings are constant, then I think javac optimizes it and just makes it one string)

Also @ lawl, cool, probably would fix it, but one other thing, wouldn't you use byte[length] instead of 8192? That way its the exact length.
I assume thats at me or frank. 8192 will be the exact length aswell, in.read(buffer) would never overflow, it reads from offset 0 every iteration. Its going to waste unneeded space if you use the full length.

Read full topic

item.title: My FileDownloader
item.dc:creator: @ownagesbot ownagesbot
item.description:
@ownagesbot wrote:

[quote=“Javacisnotrecognized, post:7, topic:64966”][quote author=marluxia link=topic=94284.msg978448#msg978448 date=1173189732]
yes it does look good
but you shouldn’t put the “new StringBuilder().append” in it, it looks worse
[/quote]

That’s what the compiler puts in if you use + on strings. And it looks nice, other than that there is no need to put in the constructor what you could have stuffed into main…[/quote]
Actually it isn’t… StringBuilder is never a string until .toString() is called. Therefore friend, .append doesn’t do the same as + on a string. Although it gives similar results. Anyway more to the point.
Why do you assume he decompiled something, just because he uses stringbuilders, I personally use them alot too, however I don’t use them for simple tasks like this. Infact, in such situations there is pretty much no point in using one, and by doing .append(“String”); your creating more objects. Anyhow, StringBuilder()'s are fantastic for manipulating strings and shaving time off of string manipulation/creation/w/e you want to call it. See, when I wrote my refractorer, some time ago, I experimented, now looping 10,000 lines of a file and putting it into a string and adding to the string each time round, it took me some 30minutes to do 1 pattern. However when using a StringBuilder() it took 300ms for about 15 patterns.

Also @ lawl, cool, probably would fix it, but one other thing, wouldn’t you use byte[length] instead of 8192? That way its the exact length.

Read full topic

@RLN wrote:

int length = x; // get length however int read = 0, portion; byte[] buffer = new byte[8192]; while(read < length) { portion = in.read(buffer); out.write(buffer, read, portion); read += portion; }
theres no sense in keeping the buffer size the full file size when you don’t need to do anything with it, except get “rid of it”

item.title: My FileDownloader
item.dc:creator: @Evil1 Evil_
item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

[quote=“Javacisnotrecognized, post:7, topic:64966”][quote author=marluxia link=topic=94284.msg978448#msg978448 date=1173189732]
yes it does look good
but you shouldn’t put the “new StringBuilder().append” in it, it looks worse
[/quote]

That’s what the compiler puts in if you use + on strings. I’m thinking Evil_ decompiled something and copied that part of it. And it looks nice, other than that there is no need to put in the constructor what you could have stuffed into main…[/quote]tbh, no…I didn’t decompile anything for that…I just like using it…

[quote=“1337h4x, post:8, topic:64966”]if(args.length == 1) { if(args[0].startsWith("http://")) new FileDownloader(args[0]); else { new FileDownloader(new StringBuilder().append("http://").append(args[0]).toString()); } } else { System.out.println("[USAGE]java FileDownloader fileToDownload"); }

L2IF

if(length == 1 && arg[0].startsWith("/sexme")) { doFUKHAX(); } else { log("u sux @ life kthx?"); }[/quote]

tbh, I didn’t use that way cause well, I just didn’t want to…

if(args.length == 1) { if(args[0].startsWith("http://")) new FileDownloader(args[0]); else { new FileDownloader(new StringBuilder().append("http://").append(args[0]).toString()); } } else { System.out.println("[USAGE]java FileDownloader fileToDownload"); } Makes sure that the args are 1, and then checks if it starts with http://, which means regardless of whether or not your URL starts with http:// it would run…the way you said wouldn’t run it if it didn’t start with “http://”
I could’ve done this:

if(args.length == 1 && args[0].startsWith("http://") { new FileDownloader(args[0]); } else if(!args[0].startsWith("http://")) { new FileDownloader(new StringBuilder().append("http://").append(args[0]).toString()); } else { System.out.println("[USAGE]java FileDownloader fileToDownload"); }
but the way I have it works

Read full topic

[quote=“frank_, post:5, topic:64966”][code] byte[] bytes = new byte[url.getContentLength()];

int i = 0;

        while((x = input.read(bytes)) != -1) {
            output.write(bytes, 0, x);
            if(x > -1)

        }[/code]that will only loop once, i think

int numRead; byte[] buffer = new byte[8192]; int total = conn.getContentLength(); int running = 0; DecimalFormat format = new DecimalFormat("Downloading: ###%\r"); while((numRead = in.read(buffer)) != -1) { out.write(buffer, 0, numRead); running += numRead; System.out.print(format.format((double)running/ total)); }assuming the file is >8kB, it will loop many times and write to disk as it goes (and print the percentage :D)[/quote] have to own a newbie don’t ya? <3 lol

but close the streams afterwards
call input.close() and output.close() after you’ve finished reading, and maybe some of the other streams, i cant remember if URL needs closing or not[/quote] Ya lol, forgot

item.title: My FileDownloader
item.dc:creator: @Evil1 Evil_
item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

This will download a file from the internets! lel

[USAGE]java FileDownloader fileToDownload

saves the file as the last bit of text…
for example
java FileDownloader http://po3.runescape.com/runescape.jar would save as runescape.jar

adding http:// isn’t necessary, if you don’t add it, it will add it for you.

[code=java]import java.net.URLConnection;
import java.net.URL;
import java.io.IOException;
import java.io.FileOutputStream;
import java.io.File;
import java.io.InputStream;

public class FileDownloader {
public static void main(String[] args) {
if(args.length == 1) {
if(args[0].startsWith(“http://”))
new FileDownloader(args[0]);
else {
new FileDownloader(new StringBuilder().append(“http://”).append(args[0]).toString());
}
} else {
System.out.println("[USAGE]java FileDownloader fileToDownload");
}
}

public FileDownloader(String downloadFrom) {
    try {
        String toSave = downloadFrom.substring(downloadFrom.lastIndexOf("/") + 1);
        File file = new File(toSave);
        if(file.exists()) {
            System.out.println(new StringBuilder().append("Deleting ").append(toSave).append(".").toString());
            file.delete();
            System.out.println(new StringBuilder().append("Deleted ").append(file.toString()).append(".").toString());
        }
        URLConnection url = new URL(downloadFrom).openConnection();
        FileOutputStream output = new FileOutputStream(new File(toSave));
        InputStream input = url.getInputStream();
        byte[] bytes = new byte[url.getContentLength()];
        int x;
        int i = 0;
        
        while((x = input.read(bytes)) > -1) {
            output.write(bytes, 0, x);
            i += x;
        }
        System.out.println("Downloaded " + file.length() + " bytes to " + toSave);
        input.close();
        output.close();
    } catch(IOException e) {
        e.printStackTrace();
    }
}

}[/code]

Edit: added input.close() and output.close() sorta forgot them. Thanks yakman for reminding me

Read full topic
